Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: (base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
(base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
(base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
(base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke
(base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
(base) And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
(base) And by his belt he baar a long panade
(base) And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
(base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
(base) Round was his face and camuse was his nose
(base) As piled as an Ape was his skulle
(base) He was a Market beter at the fulle
(base) Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
(base) That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
(base) A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
(base) And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
(base) His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
(base) A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
(base) The person of the toun hir fader was
(base) With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
(base) For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye
(base) She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
(base) For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
(base) To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
(base) And she was proud and peert as is a pye
(base) A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
(base) On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
(base) With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
(base) And she cam after in a gyte of reed
(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
(base) Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
(base) That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
(base) But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
(base) With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
(base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
(base) And eek for she was som del smoterlich
(base) She was as digne as water in a dich
(base) And ful of hoker and of bismare
(base) Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
(base) What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
(base) That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
(base) A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
(base) Of twenty yeer with outen any mo
(base) Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age
(base) In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
(base) This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was
(base) With camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
(base) With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hye
(base) But right fair was hir heer I wol nat lye
(base) The person of the toun for she was so feir
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In purpos was to maken hir his heir
(base) Bothe of his catel and his Mesuage
(base) And straunge he made it of hir mariage
(base) His purpos was to makyn hir his eire
(base) His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye
(base) In to som worthy blood of Auncetrye
(base) For holicherches good moot been despended
(base) On holicherches blood that is descended
(base) Ther fore he wolde his holy blood honoure
(base) Thogh that he holy chirche sholde deuoure
(base) Greet sokne hath this Miller out of doute
(base) With whete and malt of al the land aboute
(base) And nameliche ther was a greet Collegge
(base) Men clepeth the soler halle at Cantebregge
(base) Ther was hir whete and eek hir malt ygrounde
(base) And on a day it happed in a stounde
(base) Syk was this maunciple on a maladie
(base) Men wenden wisly that he sholde dye
(base) For which this Millere stal bothe mele and corn
(base) An hondred tyme moore than biforn
(base) For ther biforn he stal but curteisly
(base) But now he was a theef outrageously
(base) For which the wardeyn chidde and made fare
(base) But ther of sette the Millere noght a tare
(base) He craked boost and swoor it was noght so
(base) Thanne were ther yonge poure scolers two
(base) That dwelten in the halle of which I seye
(base) Testyf they were and lusty for to pleye
(base) And oonly for hir myrthe and reuerye
(base) Vp on the wardeyn bisily they crye
(base) To yeue hem leue but a litel stounde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To go to Mille and seen hir corn ygrounde
(base) And hardily they dorste leye hir nekke
(base) The Millere sholde noght stelen hem half a pekke
(base) Of corn by sleighte ne by force hem reue
(base) And at the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
(base) Iohn highte that oon and Aleyn highte that oother
(base) Of oon town were they born that highte Strother
(base) Fer in the North I kan noght telle where
(base) This Aleyn maketh redy al his gere
(base) They makyn redy al hir owen gere
(base) And on an hors the sak he caste anon
(base) Forth gooth Aleyn the clerk. and also Iohn
(base) With good swerd and with bokeler by his syde
(base) Iohn knew the wey hym neded no gyde
(base) And at the Mille the sak adoun he layth
(base) Aleyn spak first alhayl Symkyn in fayth
(base) How fares thy faire doghter and thy wyf
(base) Aleyn wel come quod Symkyn by my lyf
(base) And Iohn also how now what do ye here
(base) By god quod Iohn . Symond nede has na peere
(base) Hym bihoues serue hym self that has na swayn
(base) Or ellis he is a fool as clerkes sayn
(base) Oure maunciple I hope he wol be deed
(base) Swa werkes ay the wanges in his heed
(base) And ther fore is I come and eek Alayn
(base) To grynde oure corn and carie it heem agayn
(base) I pray yow speed vs heythen what ye may
(base) It shal be doon quod Symkyn by my fay
(base) What wol ye doon whil that it is in hande
(base) By god right by the hoper wol I stande
(base) Quod Iohn and se how the corn gas In
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Yet saw I neuere by my fader kyn
(base) How that the hoper wagges til and fra
(base) Aleyn answerde Iohn wiltow swa
(base) Thanne wol I be byneth by my crown
(base) And se how that the mele falles down
(base) In to the trogh that sal be my desport
(base) For Iohn in faith I may been of youre sort
(base) I is as ille a Millere as ar ye
(base) This Millere smyled of hir nycetee
(base) And thoghte al this nys doon but for a wyle
(base) They wene that no man may hem bigile
(base) But by my thrift yet shal I blere hir Iye
(base) For al the sleighte in hir phislophye
(base) The moore queynte crekys that they make
(base) The moore wol I stele whan I take
(base) In stede of flour yet wol I yeue hem bren
(base) The grettest clerkes been noght the wisest men
(base) As whilom to the wolf thus spak the mare
(base) Of al hir art counte I noght a tare
(base) Out of the dore he gooth ful pryuely
(base) Whan that he saugh his tyme softely
(base) He looketh vp and doun til he hath founde
(base) The clerkes hors ther as it stood ybounde
(base) Bihynde the Mille vnder a leefsel
(base) And to the hors he gooth hym faire and wel
(base) He strepeth of the bridel right anon
(base) And whan the hors was laus he gynneth gon
(base) Toward the fen ther wilde mares renne
(base) And forth with wehe thurgh thikke and thenne
(base) This Millere gooth ayein no word he seyde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But dooth his note and with the clerkes pleyde
(base) Til that hir corn was faire and wel ygrounde
(base) And whan the mele was sakked and ybounde
(base) This Iohn gooth out and fynt his hors away
(base) And gan to crye harrow and weilaway
(base) Oure hors is lost. Alayn for goddes banes
(base) Step on thy feet com of man al atanes
(base) Allas oure wardeyn has his palfrey lorn
(base) This Alayn al forgat bothe mele and corn
(base) Al was out of his mynde his housbondrye
(base) What whilk wey is he gane he gan to crye
(base) The wyf cam lepyng Inward with a ren
(base) She seyde allas youre hors gooth to the fen
(base) With wilde mares as faste as he may go
(base) Vnthank come on his hand that boond hym so
(base) And he that bettre sholde haue knyt the reyne
(base) Allas quod Iohn Aleyn for Cristes peyne
(base) Lay doun thy swerd and I wol myn alswa
(base) I is ful wight god waat as is a ra
(base) By god hert he sal nat scape vs bathe
(base) Be cockis herte he shal not a scape vs bathe
(base) Why ne had thow pit the capil in the lathe
(base) Ilhail by god Alayn thow is a fonne
(base) This sely clerkes haan ful faste yronne
(base) Toward the fen bothe Alayn and eek Iohn
(base) And whan the Millere seigh that they were gon
(base) He half a busshel of hir flour hath take
(base) And bad his wyf go knede it in a cake
(base) He seyde I trowe the clerkes were aferd
(base) Yet kan a Millere maken a clerkes berd
(base) For al his art ye lat hem goon hir weye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Lo wher he gooth ye lat the children pleye
(base) They gete hym noght so lightly by my croun
(base) Thise sely clerkes rennen vp and doun
(base) With keep keep stand stand Iossa warderere
(base) Ga whistle thow and I sal kepe hym heere
(base) But shortly til that it was verray nyght
(base) They koude noght thogh they dide al hir myght
(base) Hir capyl cacche he ran alwey so faste
(base) Til in a dych they caughte hym at the laste
(base) Wery and weet as beest is in the reyn
(base) Comth sely Iohn and with hym comth Aleyn
(base) Allas quod Iohn the day that I was born
(base) Now ar we dryuen til hethyng and til scorn
(base) Oure corn is stole men wil vs foolis calle
(base) Bothe the wardeyn and oure felawes alle
(base) And namely the Millere weilawey
(base) Thus pleyneth Iohn as he gooth by the wey
(base) Toward the Mille and Bayard in his hond
(base) The Millere sittyng by the fyr he fond
(base) For it was nyght and ferther myghte they noght
(base) But for the loue of god they hym bisoght
(base) Of herberwe and of ese as for hir peny
(base) The Millere seide agayn if ther be eny
(base) Swich as it is yet shal ye haue youre part
(base) Myn hous is streyt but ye han lerned art
(base) Ye kan by argumentz make a place
(base) A myle brood of twenty foot of space
(base) Lat se now if this place may suffise
(base) Or make it rowm with speche as is your gyse
(base) Now Symond seyde this Iohn by Seint Cutberd
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ay is thou myrie and that is faire answerd
(base) I haue herd seye men sal tak of twa thynges
(base) Swilk as he fyndes or tak swilk as he brynges
(base) But specialy I pray thee hoost deere
(base) Get vs som mete and drynke and make vs cheere
(base) And we wol payen trewely at the fulle
(base) With empty hand men may none haukes tulle
(base) Lo heere oure siluer redy for to spende
(base) This Millere in to town his doghter sende
(base) For ale and breed and rosted hem a goos
(base) And boond hir hors it sholde namoore go loos
(base) And in his owene chambre hem made a bed
(base) With shetes and with chalons faire yspred
(base) Noght from his owene bed but ten foot or twelue
(base) His doghter hadde a bed al by hir selue
(base) Right in the same chambre by and by
(base) It myghte be no bet and cause why
(base) Ther was no rowmer herberwe in the place
(base) They soupen and they speken hem to solace
(base) And drynken euere stroong ale at the beste
(base) Aboute mydnyght wente they to reste
(base) Wel hath this Millere vernysshed his heed
(base) Ful pale he was for dronke and noght reed
(base) He yexeth and he speketh thurgh the nose
(base) As he were on the quakke or on the pose
(base) To bedde he goth and with hym goth his wyf
(base) As any Iay she light was and iolyf
(base) So was hir ioly whistle wel ywet
(base) The Cradel at hir beddes feet is set
(base) To rokken and to yeue the child to sowke
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And whan that dronken al was in the Crowke
(base) To bedde wente the doghter right anon
(base) To bedde gooth Aleyn and also Iohn
(base) Ther nas namoore hem neded no dwale
(base) This Millere hath so wisly bibbed ale
(base) That as an hors he fnorteth in his sleep
(base) Ne of his tayl bihynde he took no keep
(base) His wyf bar hym a burdon a ful strong
(base) Men myghten hir routyng heren a furlong
(base) The wenche routeth eek per compaignye
(base) Aleyn the clerc that herde this melodye
(base) He poked Iohn and seyde slepest thow
(base) Herd thow euere slyk a sang er now
(base) Lo swilk a couplyng is ymel hem alle
(base) A wilde fyr on thair bodyes falle
(base) Wha herkned euere swilk a ferly thyng
(base) Ye they sal haue the flour of il endyng
(base) This lang nyght ther tydes me na reste
(base) But yet na force al sal be for the beste
(base) For Iohn seyde he als euere moot I thryue
(base) If that I may yon wenche wol I swyue
(base) Som esement has lawe shapen vs
(base) For Iohn ther is a lawe that says thus
(base) That gif a man in a point be agreued
(base) That in another he sal be releued
(base) Oure corn is stoln soothly it is na nay
(base) And we han had an ille fit to day
(base) And syn I sal haue naan amendement
(base) Agayn my los I wil haue esement
(base) By goddes saule it sal naan other be
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This Iohn answerde Aleyn auyse thee
(base) The Millere is a perilous man he sayde
(base) And if that he out of his sleep abrayde
(base) He myghte doon vs bathe a vileynye
(base) Aleyn answerde I counte hym noght a flye
(base) And vp he rist and by the wenche he crepte
(base) This wenche lay vp righte and faste slepte
(base) Til he so neigh was er she myghte espie
(base) That it hadde been to late for to crie
(base) And shortly for to seyn they were at oon
(base) Now pley Aleyn for I wol speke of Iohn
(base) This Iohn lith stille a furlang wey or two
(base) And to hym self he maketh routhe and wo
(base) Allas quod he this is a wikked Iape
(base) Now may I seyn that I is but an ape
(base) Yet has my felawe som what for his harm
(base) He has the Milleris doghter in his arm
(base) He auntred hym and has his nedes sped
(base) And I lye as a draf sak in my bed
(base) And whan this iape is told another day
(base) I sal ben halden a daf a Cokenay
(base) I wil arise and auntre it by my fayth
(base) Vnhardy is vnsely thus men sayth
(base) And vp he roos and softely he wente
(base) Vn to the Cradel and in his hand it hente
(base) And baar it softe vn to his beddes feet
(base) Soone after this the wyf hir routynt leet
(base) And gan awake and wente hir out to pisse
(base) And cam agayn and gan hir Cradel mysse
(base) And groped heer and ther but she foond noon
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Allas quod she I hadde almoost mysgoon
(base) I hadde almoost goon to the clerkes bed
(base) Ey benedicite thanne had I foule ysped
(base) And forth she gooth til she the Cradel fond
(base) She gropeth alwey forther with hir hond
(base) And foond the bed and thoghte noght but good
(base) By cause that the Cradel by it stood
(base) And nyste wher sche was for it was derk
(base) And nyste wher she was for it was derk
(base) But faire and wel she creep in to the clerk
(base) And lyth ful stille and wolde haue caught a sleep
(base) With Inne a while this Iohn the clerk vp leep
(base) And on this goode wyf he leyth on soore
(base) So murie a fyt ne hadde she nat ful yoore
(base) He priketh harde and depe as he were mad
(base) This ioly lyf han thise two clerkes lad
(base) Til that the thridde cok bigan to synge
(base) Aleyn wax wery in the dawenynge
(base) For he hadde swonken al the longe nyght

Wel ofter of the welle than of the tonne
She drank and for she wolde vertu plese
She knew wel labour but noon ydel ese
Hit was hir lust and hir most ese
But thogh this mayde tendre were of age
Yet in the brest of hir virginitee
Ther was enclosed rype and sad corage
And in gret reuerence and charitee
Hir olde poure fader fostred she
A fewe sheep spynnynge on feld she kepte
She wolde noght been ydel til she slepte
And whan she homward cam she wolde brynge
Wortes or othere herbes tymes ofte
The whiche she shredde and seeth for his lyuynge
And made hir bed ful harde and no thyng softe
And ay she kepte hir fadres lyf on lofte
With euery obeysance and diligence
That child may doon to fadres reuerence
Vp on Grisilde this poure creature
Ful ofte sithe this Markys sette his eye
As he on huntyng rood per auenture
And whan it fil that he myghte hir espie
He noght wit wantowne lookyng of folye
Hise eyen caste on hir but in sad wyse
Vp on hir cheere he wolde hym ofte auyse
Commendynge in his herte hir wommanhede
And eek hir vertu passyng any wight
Of so yong age as wel in cheere as dede
For thogh the peple hath no greet insight
In vertue he considered ful right
Hir bountee and disposed that he wolde
Wedde hir oonly if euere he wedden sholde
The day of weddyng cam but no wight kan
Telle what womman that it sholde be
For which merueille wondred many a man
And seyden whan they were in priuetee
Wol nat oure lord yet leue his vanytee
Wol he nat wedde allas the while
Why wol he thus hym self and vs bigyle
But nathelees this Markys hath doon make
Of gemmes set in gold and in Asure
Broches and rynges for Grisildis sake
And of hir clothyng took he the mesure
Of a mayde lyk to hir stature
And eek of othere aournementes alle
That vn to swich a weddyng sholde falle
The tyme of vndren of the same day
Approcheth that this weddyng sholde be
And al the palays put was in array
Bothe halle and chambres ech in his degree
Houses of office stuffed with plentee
Ther maystow seen of deynteuous vitaille
That may be founde as fer as last Ytaille
This Roial Markys richeliche arrayed
Lordes and ladys in his compaignye
The whiche that to the feste were yprayed
And of his retenue the Bachilrye
With many a sown of sondry melodye
Vn to the village of the which I tolde
In this array the righte wey han holde
Grisilde of this god woot ful Innocent
That for hir shapen was al this array
To fecchen water at a welle is went
And cometh hom as soone as euer she may
For wel she hadde herd seyd that thilke day
The Markys sholde wedde and if she myghte
She wolde fayn han seyn som of that sighte
She thoghte I wole with othere maydens stonde
That been my felawes in oure dore and se
The Markisesse and therfore wol I fonde
To doon at hom as soone as it may be
The labour which that longeth vn to me
And thanne I may at leyser hir biholde
Yf she this wey vn to the Castel holde
And as she wolde ouer the thresshfold gon
The Markys cam and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doun hir water pot anon
Bisyde the thresshfold in an Oxes Stalle
And doun vp on hir knees she gan to falle
And with sad contenance kneleth stille
Til she hadde herd what was the lordes wille
This thoghtful Markys spak vn to this mayde
Ful sobrely and seyde in this manere
Where is youre fader o Grisildis he sayde
And she with reuerence in humble cheere
Answerde lord he is al redy heere
And she goth with outen lenger lette
And to the Markys she hir fader fette
He by the hand than took this olde man
And seyde thus whan he hym hadde asyde
Ianicula I neither may ne kan
Lenger the plesance of myn herte hyde
If that thow vouche sauf what so bityde
Thy doghter wol I take er that I wende
As for my wyf vn to my lyues ende
Thow louest me I woot it wel certeyn
And art my feithful lige man ybore
And al that liketh me I dar wel seyn
It liketh thee and specially ther fore
Tel me that point that I haue seyd bifore
If that thow wolt vn to that purpos drawe
To take me as for thy sone in lawe
The sodeyn cas this man astoneyd so
That reed he weex abayst and al quakyng
He stood vnnethe seyde he wordes mo
But oonly this lord quod he my willyng
Is as ye wole ne ayeins youre likyng
I wol no thyng ye be my lord so deere
Right as yow list gouerneth this matere
Yet wol I quod this Markys softely
That in thy chambre I and thow and she
Haue a collacioun and wostow why
For I wol aske if it hir wille be
To be my wyf and rule hir after me
And al this shal be doon in thy persence
I wol noght speke out of thyn audience
And in the chambre whil they were aboute
Hir tretys which as ye shal after heere
The peple cam vn to the hous with oute
And wondred hem in how honeste manere
And tentifly she kepte hir fader deere
But outrely Grisildis wondre myghte
For neuere eft ne saw she swich a sighte
No wonder is thogh that she were astoned
To seen so greet a gest come in to place
She neuere was to swiche gestes woned
For which she looked with ful pale face
But shortly forth this matere for to chace
Thise arn the wordes that this Markys sayde
To this benygne verray feithful mayde
Grisilde he seyde ye shal wel vnderstonde
It liketh to youre fader and to me
That I yow wedde and eek it may so stonde
As I suppose ye wol that it so be
But thise demandes aske I first quod he
That sith it shal be doon in hastif wyse
Wol ye assente or ellis yow auyse
I sey this be ye redy with good herte
To al my lust and that I frely may
As me best thynketh do yow laughe or smerte
And neuere ye to grucche it nyght ne day
And eek whan I sey ye ne sey nat nay
Neither by word ne frownyng contenance
Swere this and heere I swere oure alliance
Wondrynge vp on this word quakyng for drede
She seyde lord vndigne or vnworthy
I am to thilke honour that ye me bede
But as ye wol your self right so wol I
And heere I swere that neuere willyngly
In werk ne thoght I nel yow disobeye
For to be deed thogh me were looth to deye
This is ynough Grisilde myn quod he
And forth he goth with a ful sobre cheere
Out at the dore and after that cam she
And to the peple he seyde in this manere
This is my wyf quod he that standeth heere
Honureth hire and loueth hire I preye
Who so me loueth ther is namoore to seye
And for that no thyng of hir olde gere
She sholde brynge in to his hous he bad
That wommen sholde dispoylen hir right there
Of which thise ladys were noght right glad
To handle hir clothes wher Inne she was clad
But nathelees this mayde bright of hewe
Fro foot to heed they clothed han al newe
Hir herys han they kembd that laye vntressed
Ful rudely and with hir fyngres smale
A coroune on hir heed they han ydressed
ꝙquoday tyred hire heed that longe rudely lay dressed
And sette hir ful Nowches grete and smale
Of hir array what sholde I make a tale
Sche is now fair of hew that arst was pale
Vnnethe the peple hir knew for hir fairnesse
Whan she translated was in swich richesse
This Markys hath hire spoused with a ryng
Broght for the same cause and thanne hir sette
Vp on an hors snow whyt and wel amblyng
And to his palays er he lenger lette
With ioyful peple that hir ledde and mette
Convoied hire and thus the day they spende
In reuel til the sonne gan descende
And shortly forth this tale for to chace
I seye that to this newe Markysesse
God hath swich fauour sent hire of his grace
That it ne semed nat by liklynesse
That she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in an Oxes Stalle
But norissed in an Emperours halle
Was as well tauȝt as any wiȝt in an emperours halle
To euery wight she woxen is so deere
And worshipful that folk ther she was bore
That from hir burthe knewe hir yeer by yeere
Vnnethe trowed they but dorste han swore
That to Ianicle of which I spak bifore
She doghter were for as by coniecture
Hem thoughte she was another creature
For thogh that euere vertuous was she
She was encressed in swich excellence
Of thewes goode yset in heigh bountee
And so discreet and fair of eloquence
So benygne and so digne of reuerence
And koude so the peples herte embrace
That ech hir louede that looked on hir face
Noght oonly of Saluce in the town
Publissed was the bountee of hir name
But eek bisyde in many a Regioun
If oon seyde wel another seyde the same
So spradde of hir heighe bountee the fame
That men and wommen as wel yonge as olde
Goon to Saluce on hir to biholde
Thus Walter lowely nay but roially
Wedded with fortunat honestetee
In goddes pees lyueth ful esily
At hom and outward grace ynow hath he
And for he saugh that vnder lowe degree
Was ofte vertu hyd the peple hym helde
A prudent man and that is seyn ful selde
Noght oonly this Grisildis thurgh hir wit
Koude al the feet of wifly humblenesse
But eek whan that the cas required it
The commune profit koude she redresse
Ther nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In al that land that she ne koude apese
And wisly brynge hem alle in reste andese
Thogh that hir housbond absent were anon
If gentil men or othere of hir contree
Were wrothe she wolde bryngen hem aton
So wise and rype wordes hadde she
And Iuggementz of so greet equytee
That she from heuene sent was as men wende
Peple to saue and euery wrong tamende
Nat longe tyme after that this Grisild
Was ywedded she a doghter hath ybore
Al hadde hir leuere haue had a knaue child
Glad was the Markys and the folk ther fore
For thogh a mayde child coome al bifore
She may vn to a knaue child atteyne
By liklyhede syn she nys nat bareyne
¶ Incipit tercia pars
Ther fil as it bifalleth tymes mo
Whan that this child hath souked but a throwe
This Markys in his herte longeth so
To tempte his wyf hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne myghte out of his herte throwe
This merueilous desir his wyf tassaye
Nedelees god woot he thoghte hir for tafraye
Forbere / wherfore he purposid on a day
He hadde assayed hir ynow bifore
And fond hir euere good what neded it
Hir for to tempte and alwey moore and moore
Thogh som men preyse it for a subtil wit
But as for me I seye that yuele it sit
Tassaye a wyf whan that it is no nede
And putten hir in angwyssh and in drede
For which this Markys wroghte in this manere
He cam allone a nyght ther as she lay
With steerne face and with ful trouble cheere
And seyde thus Grisilde quod he that day
That I yow took out of your poure array
And putte yow in estat of heigh noblesse
Ye haue nat that forgeten as I gesse
I seye Grisilde this persent dignitee
In which that I haue put yow as I trowe
Maketh yow nat foryetful for to be
That I yow took in poure estat ful lowe
For any wele ye mote your seluen knowe
Tak hede of euery word that I yow seye
Ther is no wight that hereth it but we tweye
Ye woot your self wel how that ye cam heere
In to this hous it is nat longe ago
And thogh to me that ye be lief and deere
Vnto my gentils ye be no thyng so
They seyn to hem it is greet shame and wo
For to be subgitz and been in seruage
To thee that born art of a smal village
And namely sith thy doghter was ybore
Thise wordes han they spoken doutelees
But I desire as I haue doon bifore
To lyue my lyf with hem in reste and pees
I may nat in this cas be recchelees
I moot doon with thy doghter for the beste
Nat as I wolde but as my peple leste
And yet god woot this is ful looth to me
But nathelees with outen your wityng
I wol nat doon but this wol I quod he
That ye to me assente as in this thyng
Shewe now youre pacience in your wirkyng
As we accorded was at the begynnyng
That ye me highte and swore in yone village
By youre bihest a fore youre fader ᵒage
That day that maked was oure mariage
Whan she hadde herd al this she noght ameued
Neither in word or cheere or contenance
For as it semed she was nat agreued
She seyde lord al lith in your plesance
My child and I with hertly obeisance
Been youres al and ye mowe saue or spille
Youre owene thyng werketh after your wille
Ther may no thyng god so my soule saue
Liken to yow that may displesen me
Ne I ne desire no thyng for to haue
Ne drede for to lese saue oonly thee vel ye
This wyl is in myn herte and ay shal be
No lengthe of tyme or deth may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage to oother place
Glad was this Markys of hir answeryng
But yet he feyned as he were nat so
Al drery was his cheere and his lookyng
Whan that he sholde out of the chambre go
Soone after this a furlang wey or two
He pryuely hath told al his entente
Vn to a man and to his wyf hym sente

A maner sergeant was this priuee man
The which that feithful ofte he founden hadde
In thynges grete and eek swich folk wel kan
Doon execucioun in thynges badde
The lord knew wel that he m loued and dradde
And whan this sergeant wiste his lordes wille
In to the chambre he stalked hym ful stille
Madame he seyde ye mote foryeue it me
Thogh I do thyng to which I am constreyned
Ye ben so wys that ful wel knowe ye
That lordes hestes mowe nat ben yfeyned
They mowe wel been biwailled or compleyned
But men mote nede vn to hir lust obeye
And so wol I ther is namoore to seye
This child I am comaunded for to take
And spak namoore but out the child he hente
Despitously and gan a cheere make
As thogh he wolde han slayn it er he wente
Grisildis moot al suffre and al consente
And as a lamb she sitteth meke and stille
And leet this crewel sergeant doon his wille
Suspecious was the diffame of this man
Suspect his face suspect his word also
Suspect the tyme in which he this bigan
Allas hir doghter that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slayn it right tho
But nathelees she neither weep ne syked
Conformynge hire to that the Markys liked
But at the laste speken she bigan
And mekely she to the Sergeant preyde
So as he was a worthy gentil man
That she moste kisse hir child er that it deyde
And on hir barm this litel child she leyde
With ful sad face and gan the child to blesse
And lulled it and after gan it kesse
And thus she seyde in hir benygne voys
Fare wel my child I shal thee neuere see
But sith I thee haue marked with the croys
Of thilke fader blessed mote he be
That for vs deyde vp on a croys of tree
Thy soule litel child I hym bitake
For this nyght shaltow dyen for my sake
I trowe that to a Norice in this cas
It hadde been hard this routhe for to se
Wel myghte a moder haue cryd allas
But nathelees so sad stedefast was she
That she endured al aduersitee
And to the Sergeant mekely she sayde
Haue here agayn youre litel yonge mayde
Goth now quod she and doth my lordes heste
But o thyng wol I pray yow of youre grace
That but my lord forbad yow at the leeste
Burieth this litel body in som place
That bestes ne no bryddes it to race
But he no word wol to that purpos seye
But took the child and wente vp on his weye
This sergeant cam vn to his lord agayn
And of Grisildis wordes and hir cheere
He tolde hym poynt for poynt in short and playn
And hym persenteth with his doghter deere
Som what this lord hadde routhe in his manere
But nathelees his purpos held he stille
As lordes doon whan they wol han hir wille
And bad this Sergeant that he pryuely
Sholde this child softe wynde and wrappe
With alle circumstances tendrely
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vp on peyne his heed of for to swappe
That no man sholde knowe of this entente
Ne whennes he cam ne whider that he wente
But at Boloigne he to his suster deere
That thilke tyme of Pauyk was Countesse
He sholde it take and shewe hir this matere
Bisekynge hir to doon hir bisynesse
This child to fostre in alle gentilesse
And whos child that it was he bad hir hyde
From euery wight for aught that may bityde
The Sergeant goth and hath fulfild this thyng
But to this Markys now retourne we
For now goth he ful faste ymagynyng
If by his wyues cheere he myghte se
Or by hir word aperceyue that she
Were chaunged but he neuere hir koude fynde
But euere in oon ylike sad and kynde
As glad as humble as busy in seruyse
And eek in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in euery maner wise
Ne of hir doghter noght a word spak she
Noon accident for noon aduersitee
Was seyn in hir ne neuere hir doghter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game
Incipit pars quarta
IN this estat ther passed ben 4 yeer
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue child she bar by this Walter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contree merye
Was for this child and god they thanke and herye
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Departed of his Norice on a day
This Markys caughte yet another lest
To tempte his wyf yet ofter if he may
O nedelees was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wyf quod this Markys ye han herd er this
My peple sikly berth this mariage
And namely sith my sone yborn is
Now is it worse than euere in al oure age
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myne erys comth the voys so smerte
That it wel neigh destroyed hath myn herte
Now sey they thus whan Walter is agon
Thanne shal the blood of Ianycle succede
And been oure lord for oother haue we noon
Swiche wordes seith my peple out of drede
Wel oghte I of swich murmur taken hede
For certeinly I drede swich sentence
Though they nat pleyn speke in myn audience
I wolde lyue in pees if that I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed outrely
As I his suster serued by nyghte
Right so thenke I to serue hym priuely
This warne I yow that ye nat sodeynly
Out of your self for no wo sholde outraye
Beth pacient and ther of I yow praye
I haue quod she seyd thus and euere shal
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certeyn
But as yow list noght greueth me at al
Thogh that my doghter and my sone be sleyn
At youre comandement this is to seyn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first siknesse and after wo and peyne
Ye ben oure lord dooth with your owene thyng
Right as yow list axeth no reed of me
For as I lefte at hom al my clothyng
Whan I first cam to yow right so quod she
Lefte I my wyl and al my libertee
And took youre clothyng wher fore I yow preye
Dooth your plesance I wol youre lust obeye
And certes if I hadde prescience
Youre wyl to knowe er ye your lust me tolde
I wolde it doon with outen necligence
But now I woot youre lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesance ferm and stable I holde
For wiste I that my deeth wolde doon yow ese
Right gladly wolde I dyen yow to plese
Deeth may nat make no comparisoun
Vn to youre loue and whan this Markys say
The constance of his wyf he caste adoun
Hise eyen two and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with drery contenance
But to his herte it was ful gret plesance
This vggly XXgeant in the same wyse
That he hir doghter caughte right so he
Or worse if men worse kan deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beautee
And euere in oon so pacient was she
That she no cheere made of heuynesse
But kiste hir sone and after gan it blesse
Saue this she prayde hym that if he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to sighte
Fro foweles and fro bestes hem to saue
But she noon answere of hym myghte haue
He wente his wey as hym no thyng roghte
But to Boloigne he tendrely it broghte
This Markys wondreth euer lenger the moore
Vp on hir pacience and if that he
Ne hadde soothly knowen ther bifoore
That perfitly hir children loued she
He wolde haue wend that of som subtiltee
And of malice or of cruel corage
That she hadde suffred this with sad visage
But wel he knew that next hym self certayn
She loued hir children best in euery wise
But now of wommen wolde I asken fayn
If thise assayes myghte nat suffise
What koude a sturdy housbond moore deuyse
To proue hir wifhod and hir stedfastnesse
And he contynuynge euere in sturdynesse
But ther ben folk of swich condicioun
That whan they haue a certeyn purpos take
And so wilful suche assayes to make
They kan nat stynte of hir entencioun
But right as they were bounden to that stake
They wol nat of that firste purpos slake
Right so this Markys fulliche hath purposed
To tempte his wyf as he was first disposed
He wayteth if by word or contenance
That she to hym was chaunged of corage
But neuere koude he fynde variance
She was ay oon in herte and in visage
And ay the ferther that she was of age
The moore trewe if that it were possible
She was to hym in loue and moore penyble
For which it semed thus that of hem two
Ther nas but o wyl for as Walter leste
The same lust was hir plesance also
And god be thanked al fyl for the beste
She shewed wel for no worldly vnreste
A wif as of hir self no thyng ne sholde
Wille in effect but as hir housbond wolde
The sclaundre of Walter ofte and wyde spradde
That of a cruel herte he wikkedly
For he a poure womman wedded hadde
Hath mordred bothe his children pryuely
Swich murmur was among hem comunly
No wonder is for to the peples ere
Ther cam no word but that they mordred were
For which wher as his peple ther bifore
Hadde loued hym wel the sclaundre of his diffame
Made hem that they hym hated therfore
To ben a mordrer is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stente
To tempte his wyf was set al his entente
Whan that this doghter xij yer was of age
He to the court of Rome in subtil wise
Enformed of his wil sente his message
Comaundynge hem swiche bulles to deuyse
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
In this maner and in this same gyse
How that the pope as for his peples reste
Bad hym to wedde another if hym leste
I seye he bad they sholde contrefete
The popes bulles makyng mencioun
That he hath leue his firste wyf to lete
As by the popes dispensacioun
To stynte rancour and dissencioun
Bitwix his peple and hym thus seyde the bulle
The which they han publissed at the fulle
The rude peple as it no wonder is
Wenden ful wel that it hadde ben right so
But whan thise tidynges cam to Grisildis
I deme that hir herte was ful wo
But she ylike sad for euere mo
Disposed was this humble creature
Thaduersitee of Fortune al tendure
Abidynge euere his lust and his plesance
To whom that she was yeuen herte and al
As to hir verray worldly suffisance
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markys writen hath in special
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of Pavyk which that hadde tho
Wedded his suster prayde he specially
To bryngen hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
With all his hert ful affectuously
But o thyng he hym prayde outrely
With all his herte ful affectuously
That he to no wight thgh men wolde enquere
Sholde nat tellen whos children that they were
But seye the mayden sholde ywedded be
Vn to the Markys of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was prayd so dide he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
And forth he rod / ful fast a noon
Toward Saluce and lordes many oon
Toward Saluce / this Mayde for to gyde
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir bisyde
Arrayed was toward hir mariage
This fresshe mayde ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which that seuen yeer was of age
Arrayed eek ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad cheere
Toward Saluces shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day they ryden in hir wey

Incipit pars qᵃnta et Vltima
This Markys yet his wif to tempte moore
To the outreste preue of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seyd hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I hadde ynogh plesance
To han yow to my wyf for your goodnesse
As for youre trouthe and for your obeysance
Noght for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sondry wyse
I may nat do as euery Plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eek the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And trewely thus muche I wol yow seye
My newe wif is comynge by the weye
Be strong of herte and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Tak it agayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous quod he
No man may alwey han prosperitee
With euene herte I rede yow tendure
The strook of Fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway
How that bitwixen youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparisoun it is no nay
I ne heeld me neuere digne in no manere
To be your wyf no ; ne youre chambrere
And in this hous ther ye me lady made
The heighe god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuere heeld me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And euere shal whil that my lyf may dure
Abouen euery worldly creature
That ye so longe of youre benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryelde it yow ther is namoore to seye
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyues ende
Ther I was fostred of a child ful smal
Til I be deed my lyf ther wol I lede
A wydewe clene in body herte and al
For sith I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyf it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbond or to make
And of youre newe wyf god of his grace
So graunte yow wele and prosperitee
For I wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For sith it liketh yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon I wol goon whan yow leste
But ther as ye me profre swich dowaire
As I first broghte it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thyng faire
The whiche to me were hard now for to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But sooth is seyd algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect it proued is on me
Loue is noght old as whan that it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersitee
To dyen in this cas it shal nat be
That euere in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lord ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me strepe out of my poure wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broghte I noght ellis out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn my clothyng I restore
And eek my weddyng ryng for euere moore
The remenant of your Iewels redy be
Inwith your chambre dar I saufly sayn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked moot I turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklees out of your palays wente
Ye koude nat doon so dishoneste a thyng
That thilke wombe in which youre children leye
Sholde biforn the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wher fore I yow preye
Lat me nat lyk a worm go by the weye
Remembre yow myn owene lord so deere
I was youre wyf thogh I vnworthy weere
Wher fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I broghte and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wont to were
That I ther with may wrye the wombe of here
That was youre wyf and here I take my leeue
Of yow myn owene lord lest I yow greeue
The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnnethes thilke word he spak
But wente his wey for routhe and for pitee
Biforn the folk hir seluen strepeth shee
And in hir smok with heued and feet al bare
Toward hir fader hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepynge in hir weye
And Fortune ay they cursen as they goon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spak she noon
Hir fader that this tidynge herde anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to been a lyues creature
For out of doute this olde poure man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euere he demed sith that it bigan
That whan the lord fulfild hadde his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his estat so lowe for talighte
And voyden hir as soone as euere he myghte
Agayns his doghter hastiliche goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myghte be
He couered hire ful sorwefully wepynge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse
As clerkes whan hem lest konne wel endite
Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wommen kan ne kan be half so trewe
As wommen been but it be falle of newe

Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come
Of which the fame vp sprong to moore and lesse
And to the peples erys alle and some
Was kouth eek that a newe Markisesse
He with hym broghte in swich pomp and richesse
That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently and wysly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
Here may ye se the peple how newe
For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
And changeable be right as the mane
Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To han a newe lady of hir town
Namoore of this make I now mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the feste was apertinent
Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man aparceyueth
But ay they wondren what she myghte be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koude swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostred in hir norissynge
Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude nat aduersitee endure
As koude a poure fostred creature
And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad cheere and no malice at al
And he so ofte had doon to hir offence
And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
With pacience Grisild he quiteth
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
Mankynde which that he wroght
As wel as euere womman was assayed
In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wyf that oother feithfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
And nat to sleen my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
O which a pitous thyng it was to se
O such a pitous thing it was to see
Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
The children from hir arm they gonne arace
O many a teer o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
With a coroune of many a riche stoon
Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
And ther she was honured as hir oghte
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and womman dooth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
This feste was and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage
Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
And richely his doghter maried he
Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
His sone succedeth in his heritage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eek his mariage
Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is nat so strong it is no nay
As it hath been in olde tymes yore
And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
For it were inpor table thogh they wolde
But for that euery wight in his degree
Sholde be constant in aduersitee
As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
For sith a womman was so pacient
Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
He preueth folk al day it is no drede
And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
Er we were born knew al oure freletee
And for oure beste is al his gouernance
Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a town Grisildis thre or two
For if that they were put to swiche assayes
The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
For which heere for the wyues loue of Bathe
Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene
In heigh maistrie or ellis were it scathe
I wol with lusty herte fressh and grene
Seye yow a song to glade yow I wene
And lat vs stynte of ernestful matere
Herkneth my song that seith in this manere

(base) He nys no fool ne no demonyak
(base) And Iankyn hath ywonne a newe gowne
(base) My tale is doon we been almoost at towne
(base) Here endeth the Somnours tale
(base) Hic finita fabula Summonitoris

div.l: Hoo qd þᵉ knyht nomore of this
Þᵗat ȝe haue seyd is ryht ynowh ywys
And muchel more for lyttel heuynesse
Is ryht ynowh to muchel folk y gesse
Ȝoure tales doth vs no desport ne game
Wherfore ʆser/sir monke or dan piers be ȝoure name
I pᵃy ȝowe hertely telleth sıı̄unwhat elles
For syker nere chinking of ȝoure belles
Þat on ȝoure brydell hangeth on euʳy syde
By heuene king þat for vs all died
I sholde or this haue falle doun for slep
All þauh þᵉ slowh had be neuʳ so dep
Then had ȝoure tale be told in veyn
For certeyn as þese clerkes seyn
Where as a man may haue non audience
Nouht helpeth to telle his sentence
As well y wot þᵉ substaunce is in me
Ȝif any þing shall wel reported be
Syre say somewhat of hontynge y ȝow pᵃy
Nay qd þᵉ monke y haue no lust to play
Nowe let an oþʳ telle vs as I haue told
Thenne speke oure ost wᵗith rude speche ⁊and bold
And seyde vn to þᵉ Nōmnes prest anon
Come nere ʆser/sir prest come hyther ʆser/sir Iohn
Telle vs of such þing as may oure hertes glade
Be mery þauh þᵘ ride vpon a Iade
All theigh þin hors be foule ⁊and lene
Ȝif he wyl sue þe rekke þᵘ not a bene
Loke þat þin herte be mery euʳmoo
Ȝis ʆser/sir ost qd he as mot I goo
But I be mery ywys y wyl be blamed
And right anon he hath his tale attamed
And þus he seyde vn to vs euʳychon
Thys swete prest þis gode man ʆser/sir Iohn
The nonis prest
A Pore wydowe some dele stope in age
Was whylom dwellynge in a narowe cage
Bysyde a grofe standynge in a dale
This wydowe of whiche y tolde ȝow my tale
Sythns þilke day þᵗat she was last a wyf
In pacience lad a full symple lyf
For lyttell was here catell ⁊and here rent
By housbandrye such as god her sent
She fond hereself ⁊and eke hure douhtren two
Thre large cowes had she ⁊and no mo
Thre kyne ⁊and eke a sheep þᵗat heiht malle
Full sytye was hure boure ⁊and eke here halle
In whiche she ete many a sklendre mele
Of poynant sauce her neded neủer/re adele
No deynte morsell passed here throte
Her diet was accordaunt to here cote
Replecioun ne made here neuʳ seke
A tempre diete was all here phisike
And excercise and hertes suffisaunce
Þᵉ goute letted here no þing to daunce
Ne poplexie ne shent not here hed
Ne wyn ne drank she not whyte ne reed
Here bord was serued most wᵗith whyte ⁊and blak
Mylke ⁊and broune bred in whiche she fond no lak
Some tyme bacon ⁊and some tyme an ey or twey
For she was a man of a deye
A gardeyn she had enclosed all aboute
Wᵗith stykkes ⁊and drye dych wᵗith oute
In whiche she had a cok þᵗat height chaunte clere
In all þᵉ land of crowynge was his pere
His voys was merioᵘur þan þᵉ mery organ
On masse dayes þat in þᵉ chyrche gon
Wel syker was his crowynge in his logge
Than is a clok or in any Abbey Orloge
By nature he knewe yche ascensioun
Of þᵉ equenoxial of þilke toun
For whenne degrees xv . weren ascended
Thenne crewe he þᵗat hit myht not ben amended
His comb was radder þan þᵉ fyne corall
And batayled as hit were a castell wall
His byle was blak ⁊and as þᵉ gete hit shon
Lyke asure weren his legges ⁊and his ton
His nayles whitter þan þᵉ lylly flour
And ylike bornisshed gold was his colour
This gentel cok had in his goủer/renaunce
Vij hennes for to do his plesaunce
Whiche were his sostres ⁊and his ꝑper/paramoᵘurs
And wondre lyke to hym as of coloures
Of whyche þᵉ fayrest hewed on þᵉ throte
Was cleped fayre damysell ꝑper/partilote
Curteys she was discrete ⁊and debonayre
And compenable ⁊and bare here self so fayre
Sithns þilke day þat she was seue nyht old
Þᵗat trewely she hath þᵉ hert in hold
Of chaunteclere to loken on euʳy lyth
He loued her so þᵗat wo was hym þ̉er/rewyth
But such a Iape as was to here hym synge
Whenne þᵗat þᵉ bryht sonne gan to springe
In a swete acord my lief is ferre in land
For þilke tyme as y haue vndurstand
Bestes ⁊and bryddes couthe speke ⁊and syng
And so befel þat in a dawenyng
Chaunteclere among his wyfes all
Sate on þᵉ perche þat was in þᵉ hall
And next hym sat þis feyre ꝑper/partelot
Þis chaunteclere gan gronen in his throte
As a man þat is in his dreme drecched sore
And whenne þat ꝑper/partilot þus herde hym rore
She was agast ⁊and seyde herte dere
What eyleth ȝow to grone in þis manere
Ȝe ben a verrey sleꝑper/par fy for shame
And he answered ⁊and seyde thus madame
Y pᵃy ȝowe take hit not agreef
By god me mette I was in suche mys chief
Ryht nowe þᵗat ȝut myn hert is sore afryht
Nowe qd he my sweuen recche aryht
And kepe my body out of foule pⁱrisoun
Me mette þat I romed vp and doun
Wᵗith inne oure ȝord where as I see abest
Was lyke an hounde ⁊and wolde haue mad arest
Vpon myn body and wolde haue had me ded
His coloᵘur was bytwyx whyte ⁊and red
And typped was his tayle ⁊and bothe his eres
Wᵗith blak vn lyke þᵉ remenant of his heres
His snovte was smalle wᵗith glowynge eyen twey
Ȝit of his loke almost for fere I deye
This caused me my gronyng douteles
Awey qd she fy on ȝow herteles
Allas qd she for by þat god aboue
Nowe haue ȝe lost myn herte ⁊and my loue
I can not loue a coward by my feth
For certes what so any womman seyth
We all desyren hit ȝif hit myhte be
To haue housebandes hardy wyse ⁊and fre
And secre ne no nygard ne no fole
Ne hym þᵗat is agast of euʳy tole
Ne non auauntoᵘur by þat god aboue
How durste ȝe sey fer for shame vn to ȝoure loue
Þᵗat any þing myhte make ȝow aferd
Haue ȝe no mannes herte ⁊and haue a berd
Allas ⁊and conne ȝe ben agast of dremes
Þt comen to ȝow vpon þᵉ bemes
Sweuenes engenderen of replexiouns
And often of fume ⁊and of complexiouns
Whenne humoᵘurs ben to habundaunt in a wyght
Certes þis dreme which ȝe haue herd to nyht
Cometh of þᵉ grete suꝑper/parfluite
Of þᵉ rede Colre ꝑper/pardee
Whiche causeth folk to dremen her dremes
Of arowes ⁊and of fyre wᵗith rede lemes
Of rede bestes þat woln hem byte
Of contek ⁊and of welpes grete ⁊and lite
Ryht as þᵉ humoᵘur malincolyke
Causeth many a man in slep to crie
For fere of beres and boles blake
Or elles blake deueles wyl hym take
Of oþʳe humoᵘurs can I telle also
Þᵗat wyrchen many aman in slep full wo
But I wylle passe as lythly as I can
Lo caton whiche þat was so wyse aman
Seyde he not thus . ne do no force of dremes
Nowe ʆser/sir qd she whenne ȝe flee fro þᵉ bemes
For godes loue as tak some laxatyf
Vp ꝑper/paril of my soule ⁊and of my lyf
I counsell ȝowe þᵉ best y wyl not lye
Þat beth of colre ⁊and malincolie
Ȝe purge ȝow ⁊and for ȝe shull not tarie
Geteth ȝow nowe some letuarie
I shall my self to herbes techen ȝow
Þat shull be for ȝoure hele ⁊and for ȝoure prow
And in þᵉ gardeyn þᵉ herbes shall y fynde
Þᵉ whiche haue here ꝓproprete by kynde
To purgen ȝow bynethe ⁊and eke aboue
Forgeteth not þis for godes owne loue
Ȝe ben ful Coliryk of complexioun
Were þᵉ sonne in his ascensioun
I fynde ȝow replete of humoᵘurs hote
And ȝif hit do I dar wel ley a grote
Þᵗat ȝe shull haue a feuoᵘur certayne
Or an agwe þat may be ȝoure bane
A day or two ȝe shull haue digestyues
Of wormes or ȝe take ȝoure laxatyues
Of laureol Centorie ⁊and fumetere
Or elles of Ellebore þat groweth þ̉er/ree
Of catapuce or of gayte beryes
Of Erbe Ive growynge in ȝoure ȝord þ̉er/ree mery is
Pekke hem vp as þey growen ⁊and ete hem In
Beth mery housbande for ȝoure fadʳ kyn
Dredeth no dreme y can sey no more
Ma dame qd he gᵃunt mercy of ȝoure lore
But neuʳþeles as touchynge daun Catoun
Þᵗat hath of wysdome suche a grete renoun
By god men may in olde bokes rede
Diủer/rese auctorites hit is no drede
Of many an oþʳ man more of auctorite
Then euʳ Catou was so mote y thee
Þᵗat all þᵉ reuers seyen of this sentence
And haue well yfounden by exꝑper/parience
Þᵗat dremes ben significaciouns
As well of Ioye as of tⁱbulaciouns
Þᵗat folk enduren in this lyf psent
Þ̉er/ree nedeth not to make of þis non argument
Þᵉ verrey preef sheweth hit in dede
Oon þᵉ grettest auctor þat men may rede
Seyth þus þat whylom two felawes went
On pylgⁱmage in a full good entent
And happed so þᵗat þei comen in to a toun
Where as was such congregacioun
Of peple ⁊and eke of streyte herbygage
That þei fond not as muche as a Cotage
In whyche þei bothe myhte logged be
Þ̉er/refore þei moste of necessite
As for þᵗat nyht departen companye
And yche of hem goth to his Ostelerie
And toke his loggyng as hit wolde falle
Þᵗat oon of hem was logged in a stalle
Ferre in a ȝord wᵗith oxen of þᵉ plouh
Þat oþʳ man was logged well ynouh
And as was aduenture ⁊and his fortune
Þᵗat vs gouerneth all in cōmmune
And so befell longe or hit were day
Þis man mette in his bedde þ̉er/ree as he lay
How þᵗat his felawe can on hym calle
And seyde allas for in an oxe stalle
Þis nyht shall y be murdred þ̉er/ree y lye
Now helpe me dere brother or y dye
In all haste come to me he seyde
This man oute of his slep for fere abreyde
But whenne he waked out of his slep
He tʳned hym and toke of þis no kep
Hym þouhte his dreme was but a vanite
Thus twyes in his slep dremed he
And at þe thrydde tyme ȝit his felawe
Cam as hym þouhte I am nowe slawe
Beholde my blody woundes deepe ⁊and wyde
Arise vp erly in þᵉ morowe tyde
And at þᵉ west gate of þᵉ toun qd he
A cart full of donge þ̉er/ree shalt þᵘ see
In whiche my body is hid full pⁱriuely
Do thilke Cart aresten full boldely
My gold caused my mordre soth to seyne
And tolde hym euʳy poynt howe he was slayne
Wᵗith a full pytouse face pale of hewe
And tresteth wel his drem he fond ful trewe
For on þᵉ morowe as sone as hit was day
To his felawe he took þᵉ nexte way
And whenne he cam to þᵉ oxe stalle
Aftʳ his felawe he began to calle
Þᵉ Osteler answered hym anon
And seyde syre ȝoure felawe is gon
As sone as day he went oute of þᵉ toun
Þis man can falle in grete suspecioun
Remembrynge on his dremes þᵗat he mette
And forth he goth no lengʳ wolde he lette
Vnto þᵉ west gate of þᵉ toune ⁊and fond
A donge Cart wente as hit were to donge lond
Þᵗat was arrayed in þᵉ same wyse
As ȝe haue herd þis dede man deuise
And wᵗith an hardy voys he began to crye
Vengeaunce ⁊and Iustice of this felonie
My felawe murdred is þis same nyht
And in þis Cart he lyth gapynge vpryht
Þᵉ dede man þᵗat murdred was all newe
O blesfull god þᵗat art so blesfull ⁊and trewe
Lo howe þᵗat þᵘ bewryest murdre alwey
Murdre wyl out þᵗat see we day by day
Murdre is so wlatsom ⁊and abhominable
To god þat is so Iust ⁊and resonable
Þat he wyl not suffre hit heled be
Theyh hit abyde a ȝere or two or thre
Murdre wyl oute þis is my conclusioun
And ryht anon þᵉ mynystres of þᵉ toun
Haue hent þᵉ cart̉er/ree ⁊and sore hym peyned
And eke þᵉ Osteler so ferre engyned
Þat þei beknewe here wyckednesse anon
And weren hanged by þᵉ necke bon
Here men may seen þat dremes ben to drede
And certes in þᵉ same book y rede
Ryht in þᵉ nexte chapitre aftʳ þis
I gabbe not so haue I Ioye ⁊and blys
To men þᵗat wolde haue passed þᵉ see
For c̉er/reteyne cause in to ferre contre
Ȝif þᵗat þᵉ wynde nad be þᵉ contᵃrie
Þat made hem in Citee forto tarie
Þat stod full mery vpon an hauen syde
But on a day agayns þᵉ Euen tyde
Þᵉ wynd began to blowe ⁊and chaunge as hym lyst
Iolyf ⁊and glad þei wenten vn to rest
And casten hem full Erly for to seyle
But herkene howe þᵗat þᵉ oo man fell īm a gret ꝑper/parile
That oon of hem in slepynge as he lay
He mette a wondre dreme agayns þᵉ day
Hym thouhte a man stod by his beddes syde
And hym cōmmaunded þat he shulde abyde
And seyde þus ȝif þᵘ to morowe wende
Þᵘ shalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende
He awook ⁊and tolde his felawe what he mette
And pᵃyede hym his viage forto lette
As for þᵗat day he pᵃyede hym for to abyde
His felawe lay by his beddes syde
And began forto lawhe ⁊and scorne hym ful fast
Ne dreme qd he may make myn herte agast
Þᵗat I wyl lette for to do my thinges
I sette not a strawe by þy dremynges
For sweuenes beth but vanitees ⁊and Iapes
Men dreme alwey of oules ⁊and of apes
But sithns I see þᵗat þᵘ wylt here abyde
And þ9 for slewthe wylfully þi tyde
God wot hit reweth me ⁊and haue good day
And thus he toke his leue ⁊and wente his way
And er þᵗat he hadde half his cours ysayled
But y not why no what mys chaunce hit eyled
But casuelly þᵉ shyppes botom rent
And shyp ⁊and man vndʳ þᵉ watʳ went
In syht of oþʳe shyppes hym besyde
Þat wᵗith hym seyled at þᵉ same tyde
And þ̉er/refore seyde he ꝐPer/Partelot so dere
By such ensaumple olde mayst þᵘ lere
Þat no man sholde be recheles
Of dremes for I sey þe douteles
Þat many a dreme ful sore is for to drede
Lo in þᵉ lyf of seynt kenelme y rede
Þᵗat was kenulphes sone þᵉ noble kyng
Of merreyng howe kenelme mette athyng
A lyttel or he were murdred on a day
His murther in his auisioun he sey
His norice hym expouned euʳy dele
His sweuen ⁊and bad hym for to kepe hym well
From treson but he was to bold
And þ̉er/refore lyttel tale hath he told
Of any dreme so holly was his hert
By god me had leuer þan my shert
Þat ȝe had herd þis legende as haue I
Dame ꝑper/partelot y sey nowe trewely
Macrobeus þat wryteth þᵉ auisioun
In Affryk of þᵉ worthy Cyprioun
Affermeth dremes ⁊and seyth þ̉er/re ben
Warnynge of þinges þᵗat men aftʳ seen
And forthermore y þᵃy ȝow loketh well
Þᵉ olde testament of Danyell
Ȝif he hyld dremes of any vanite
Redeth eke of Ioseph ⁊and ȝe shull see
Wheþʳ dremes ben sıı̄untyme y sey not all
Warnynge of þinges þat shull aftʳ falle
Loke of Egypt þᵉ kyng daun pharoo
His bakere ⁊and his Boteler also
Wheþʳ þei ne felde non effect in dremes
Who so wyl seche þᵉ acte of sondry remes
May reden of dremes many a wondʳ þing
Lo Cresus whiche was of lyde kyng
Mette he not þᵗat he sate vpon a tre
Whiche signified þat he shulde an hanged be
Lo here Adromocha Ectores wyf
Þᵗat day þat Ectore shulde lose his lyf
She dremed on þᵉ same nyht aforn
Howe þᵗat þᵉ lyf of Ector shulde be lorn
Ȝif þilke day he wente in to batayle
She warned hym but hit myhte not a vayle
He wente for to fyhten neuʳþeles
But he was slayne of Achilles
But þilke tale is to long to telle
And eke hit is nyht y may no lengʳ dwelle
Shortly y sey as for conclusioun
That y shall haue of þis avisioun
Of adủer/resite and y sey ferthermore
That y wyl telle of laxatyfes no more
For þei ben venymes y wot ryht well
I hem defye y loue hem neuʳ a dell
Nowe let vs speke of myrthe ⁊and stynte all þis
Madame ꝐPer/Partelot so haue y blys
Of oo þing god hath send me large gᵃce
For whenne y see þᵉ beaute in ȝoure face
Ȝe ben so skarlet rede aboute ȝoure eyen
Hit maketh all my drede for to dyen
For als syker as In pⁱrincipio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame þᵉ sentence of þis lateyn is
Womman is mannes Ioye ⁊and his blis
For whenne y felde a nyht ȝoure softe syde
Al be hit þat y may not on ȝow ryde
For þᵗat oure ꝐPer/Parche is made so narowh allas
I am so full of Ioye and solas
Þᵗat y defye bothe sweuenes ⁊and dremes
And wᵗith þat word he fleyh doun of þᵉ bemes
For hit was day ⁊and eke his hennes all
And wᵗith a chuk he can hem calle
For he had founden a corn ley in þᵉ ȝord
Reall he was and no more a ferd
He fethered ꝑper/partelot twenty tyme
And trade as ofte or hit were pⁱrime
He loked as hit were agrym lyoun
And on his toon he romed vp ⁊and doun
Hym deyned not to sette his feet to grounde
Ay chikked he whenne he had a corn yfounde
And to hym þan ranne his wyfes all
Thus real as a pⁱrince in his hall
Leue y þus chaunteclere in his pasture
And aftʳ wyl y telle of his aduenture
Whenne þᵉ moneth in þᵉ wyche þᵉ world began
Þᵗat heyght marche fyrst when god made man
Was complete ⁊and passed was also
Sythns marche began xxxᵗⁱ . dayes ⁊and two
Befell þat chaunteclere in all his pⁱride
His seuen wyfes walkynge hym besyde
Cast vp his eyen to þᵉ bryht sonne
Þᵗat in þᵉ signe of taurus was ronne
Twenty degrees ⁊and oon ⁊and some what more
And knewh by kynde ⁊and by non oþʳ lore
Þᵗat hit was pⁱrime ⁊and crewe wᵗith blysfull steuene
Þᵉ sonne he seyde is clomben in to heuene
Xlᵗⁱ degrees ⁊and oon ⁊and more ywys
Ma dame ꝑper/partelot my worldes blys
Herken howe this blysfull bryddes synge
And see þᵉ fressh floures howe þei sprynge
Full is my hert of Reuel ⁊and of solace
But sodeynly hym fell a sorowefull case
For euʳ þᵉ lattre ende of Ioye is sone ago
By þese ensaumples ⁊and by mony mo
Ȝif a rethoure couthe fayre endyte
He in Cronicle myhte sauely wryte
As for a soủer/reeygne notabilite
Nowe euʳy wysman herken me
This storie is also trewe y vndertake
As is þᵉ book of launcelot þᵉ lake
Þᵗat wymmen huld in full grete reủer/reence
Nowe wylle y turne agayn to my sentence
A Colfox felle of sleyght ⁊and iniquite
Þᵗat in þᵉ grove had woned ȝeres þre
By heigh ymaginacioun afore cast
Þᵉ same nyht þoruh oute þᵉ hegge barst
In to þᵉ ȝord þ̉er/ree chaunteclere þᵉ feyre
Was wond ⁊and eke his wyf to repeyre
And in a bed of wortes stylle he lay
Tyl hit was passed vndren of þᵉ day
Waytynge his tyme on chaunteclere to falle
As gladly don þise homicides alle
Þᵗat in a wayte lyggen to murthere men
O false murdrour roukyng in þi den
O newe scarioth ⁊and newe geneloun
Fals dissimilour o greek synoun
Þat brouhtest troye all vttrely to sorowe
O chaunteclere O cursed be þat morowe
Þᵗat þᵘ into þᵉ ȝord fleyh fro þᵉ bemes
Þᵘ were full wel warned by þi dremes
Þat þilke day was ꝑper/parelouse to þe
But þat god wote a fore wylle nedes be
Aftʳ þᵉ oppinioun of certeyn clerkes
Wytnesse on hym þat any clerk is
Þᵗat in scole grete alt̉er/recacioun
In þis matere ⁊and gret disputacioun
And hath ben of an hundred þousand men
But I ne can bulte hit to þe bren
As can þᵉ holy doctoᵘur Austyn
Or boyce or þᵉ bysshop Bradwardyn
